The map at 1:09 leaves out the North Caucasus (aka Kavkaz). This is the region to the northeast of Turkey and west of asia. Leaving it out is imho a big oversight because of just how important Chechnya (and to a lesser extent Dagestan and Akbhazia) have been in the context of global jihad.

Many Arabs fought in Chechnya during the 1990s as part of Ibn Al-Khattab's force. In the 1980s a significant part of the anti Soviet forces were Chechen (this would also become relevant later in the 1990s when all those Chechens returned home). In fact Vladimir Putin essentially came to power due to the Chechen wars, which in the eyes of Russians proved Yeltsin as weak and Putin as "strong", ignoring the vile war crimes both Yeltsin and Putin committed in Chechnya (around 1/3rd of Chechens were killed, gravely injured or were forced out, that's a higher proportion than Syria).

With the second Chechen war (1999-2009) the IIB (Islamic International Brigade) became a much more significant force in the North Caucasus, this would lead to many Arabs fighting in Chechnya and building contacts with Chechens. When the USA invaded Iraq these Arabs then asked these Chechens for help and thousands came. Chechens were the best of the Mujahiden in Iraq, both Iraqi and American sources agree on this. Fallujah had a particularly high nunber of Chechens, part of the reason the city was so bloody.

The large number of Chechen Mujahedin leaving Chechnya for the middle east drained the Chechen struggle of manpower. By the 2010s the Chechen insurgency was dying out and mostly could only perform minor attacks occasionally. However the Chechen wars had enabled Putin to consolidate power, being an extremely important factor in why modern Russian government policy looks the way it does today.

Not sure if anyone sees this comment, but to quell myths, the US did not invade Iraq for its oil, and this cop-out answer is kinda dangerous. The US gets most of its oil domestically, it is not dependent on foreign oil (which was really code for "ramp up domestic drilling). As for imports, according to the US Energy Information Administration, the countries it imports the most from is Canada (49%), Mexico (7%), Saudi Arabia (6%), Russia (6%), and Columbia (4%). And like this video says, it would be much cheaper to just import the oil. So no, the US did not invade Iraq for its oil.

So why did the US invade Iraq in 2003? Quite simply to regain American influence in the region. Saddam Hussein was pretty anti-American. Three years prior to the invasion, he switched the country from trading oil in US dollars to trading oil in their local currency. He and Saudi Arabia, a strong ally of the US, had terrible relations. Rumors of weapons of mass destruction (which were never found) were the excuse needed to invade the country and topple the government. Once the US finally left in 2011, it left in place the authoritarian federal Iraqi government. In effect, the US replaced one authoritarian government with a pro-American authoritarian government. Quite frankly, if Iraq is to ever become stable, it won't be because of the US. A pro-American dictatorship is a lot safer for US interests than a democracy for Iraqi citizens who have a negative view of the US.

It's important to be real about the motives behind the invasion. Saying it was about oil is a simple cop-out answer that does nothing to highlight the real answer. It was to regain influence over the region because the US sensed Iraq was becoming too independent.

Another one: some claim it was because Saddam Hussein had chemical weapons and was using them against citizens. It is true that he had chemical weapons, and he used them against the ethnic Kurdish population in northern Iraq. However, the Kurdish Genocide happened in 1989, and when the US invaded in 2003, the only chemical weapons they found were already decommissioned. If this was the motive for invasion, the time for that had long passed. The First Gulf War already happened in 1991, so if genocide was enough of a motive, that would be the time to depose Hussein. Ethnic cleansing and chemical weapons were definitely not a motive for the Bush administration.

While I didn't agree with the reasons we went to war in Iraq, once we were there I feel the most disastrous thing to do was pull out. And almost immediately after Obama gave a timeframe for withdrawal the Islamic State just bided their time. Then after full withdrawal they began their rampage of terror and destruction.

While an unpopular opinion, I advocated for the US military to remain in Iraq semi-indefinitely. like the situation in Korea, pulling out completely would have just allowed North Korea to conquer the South at their leisure. And I felt that we should have remained in Iraq. If anything we could have built up a strong ally in the region to help curb terrorism, and have more influence in both Syria and Iran.

Now, again, I don't think we should have gotten involved in Iraq at all. Yes, police Saddam, who was clearly a terrible person who I'm glad is now gone. But going in just to depose him was a bad idea.

However, once we were there, anti-war sentiments, which weren't entirely wrong, really blinded people to the threat of ISIS, and other things. I knew as soon as we pulled out of Iraq that Al Qeada, or an Al Qaeda-like group would immediately exploit the area.

I don't have the answers for what we should do next. Part of me accepts that the damage has already been done, maybe irreversibly so. But as long as we take a half in, half out approach we just continue to make things worse.

And really, I have no faith that Trump could do anything right. Love them, or hate them, depending on which political side you adhere to, both Bush and Obama were immeasurably more competent than Trump, and they both screwed up on Iraq. Trump would just be out of his depth. That's also why I'm terrified that Trump has been upping the rhetoric against North Korea, the last thing I want is another war, and Trump would fumble the whole thing.

I do think the North Korean government is one of the most oppressive on Earth today, and I would like to see the regime fall. But Trump isn't the one to do it. Perhaps no American should even be involved in the fall of North Korea at all. But especially not Trump.

Homelessness in the United States
From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

Homeless American
Homelessness in the United States of America is an area of concern for social service providers, government officials, policy professionals, and society at large.[1] Although the U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development in January 2012 annual point-in-time count found that 633,782 people across the United States were homeless, other counts vary widely. In a recent approximation, an estimated 1.6 million unduplicated persons used transitional housing or emergency shelters. Of these people, approximately 1/3 are members of households with children, a nine percent increase since 2007. Another approximation is from a study done by the National Law Center on Homelessness and Poverty, which states that approximately 3.5 million people, 1.35 million of them children, are likely to experience homelessness in a given year (National Law Center on Homelessness and Poverty, 2007).[2] With 2007 as a benchmark, the data from the report showed a 6.8 percent decline in homelessness among individuals, a 3.7 percent decline of homeless families, a 13.1 percent decline of the unsheltered homeless population, and a 19.3 percent decline in persons experiencing chronic homelessness.[3]

One out of 50 children or 1.5 million children in America will be homeless each year.[4] In 2013 that number jumped to one out of 30 children, or 2.5 million.[5] There were an estimated 57,849 homeless veterans estimated in the United States during January 2013; or 12 percent of all homeless adults. Just under 8 percent of homeless U.S. veterans are female. Texas, California and Florida have the highest numbers of unaccompanied homeless youth under the age of 18; comprising 58% of the total homeless under 18 youth population [6]

Because of turnover in the homeless population, the total number of people who experience homelessness for at least a few nights during the course of a year is thought to be considerably higher than point-in-time counts. A 2000 study estimated the number of such people to be between 2.3 million and 3.5 million.[7][8] According to Amnesty International USA, vacant houses outnumber homeless people by five times.[9]

+Nameguy You are comparing apples and oranges.
1. Happiness =/= approval rating
Do the American people have low approval of leadership? Of course, we almost always do. But the reasons we do not approve our leadership is because of matters that are so radically different than that of countries in the middle east. We argue about universal healthcare while countries like Iraq are struggling to even have medical equipment. Americans disagree on military spending, while Iraq's military is almost non existent. Do I disagree with a lot of action that the U.S. is taking? Of course, but I would rather live here in peace and freedom than in the Middle East where approval ratings mean absolutely nothing to oppressive regimes.

2. Are you seriously comparing NSA/SOPA to abuse by other governments?
The NSA, although something I am against, is no where near the level of intrusion that countless other governments take. Think about it, we are here arguing about whether our government can record just basic data about phone calls (which can only be accessed by a warrant sent to the phone company) while many Middle Eastern countries regularly go through unwarranted and violent searches and seizures, are regularly denied the rights to speak out and of press, and often do not have basic human rights.

3. Poor or low income in the U.S. =/= poor or low income in Iraq
You have to be an absolute moron if you believe that wages in both countries, and the standards surrounding them, are the same. 1/4th of Iraqis live on only a few dollars everyday. A minimum wage job in the United States could pay almost $60 in the same amount of time.

The United States is by far the world’s largest arms trader, accounting for around 30 per cent of conventional arms transfers in terms of value. Its position on the ATT is therefore key.Countries suppliedThe USA supplies arms to more than 170 countries and has a mixed record of suspending arms supplies on human rights grounds. For example, it has restricted arms transfers to Myanmar, China, Sri Lanka and Zimbabwe in addition to countries subject to UN arms embargoes. However, it has supplied arms to other countries, for example Sri Lanka, Bahrain, Egypt and Yemen, where there is a substantial risk that they could be used to commit of facilitate serious human rights violations. Irresponsible transfersAs the main arms supplier to Egypt, the US authorized the sale of small arms, millions of rounds of ammunition and chemical agents for riot control, despite the security forces’ violent crackdown on protesters. Yemen was also supplied with small arms, chemical agents and armoured vehicles, and Bahrain with small arms. It provides Colombia’s security forces with arms, military aid and training, despite their persistent violations of human rights. Stance on the ATTSince October 2009, when the Obama administration reversed previous opposition to an ATT, US support has been crucial in getting to the current negotiation stage. The US has said it wants the treaty to raise the international standard for export control of armaments as close as possible to that of the US. However, the US position is weaker on human rights protection in the treaty than many of its allies. For example, US officials have not wanted to include obligations on states to prohibit transfers of arms even where there is credible evidence of their potential use for serious violations of human rights. US officials have also argued against including ammunition under the scope of the treaty, claiming it is too sensitive and would pose technical problems of implementation. Overall, US officials would prefer a short loose document that spells out general principles to “take into account” rather than strong binding measures.

In spite of the usual “the CIA has failed us” blather from the major media drones, ISIS has, for the last decade, been well known by the US government and anyone else caring to pay attention to the PR department of the ISIS gang. When we read news reports that claim that the US government was, until this week, left in the dark concerning ISIS, we are reading analysis that is either from a fantastically uninformed source or from someone who simply invents fake news to suit their boss’s political agendas. ISIS has been well known under a variety of names to even the most feeble Western intelligence organizations since at least May of 2004, when the group web-published video of their execution of US contractor Nick Berg. Even if the CIA wanted to hide the existence of ISIS, it could not have done so, as ISIS has never tried to be particularly secretive. On the contrary, they have always done their best to garner as much media attention as possible, and they have always been clear about their objectives.

So who is this group that seems to be surprising so many oblivious “reporters”?
In the broadest terms, there are three main intransigent political groups in Iraq—the Shia, the Sunnis, and the Kurds. The Shia Arab group is in power and is ruling with the same lack of skill that we would expect from any other Iraqi political coalition. The Shia block and their grossly incompetent and very corrupt Iraqi Prime Minister Nouri al-Maliki have made little effort to protect the interests of the Kurdish minority in northern Iraq or the large Sunni minority scattered around Iraq.

The uprising in Syria was started by moderate Syrians in a desperate hope to find freedom. Iran quickly moved to help keep their obedient Assad servants in power. In response, Iran’s Shia Hezbollah militia went on a campaign to consolidate their power in Lebanon and Syria. Sunni radicals of various stripes banded together under the ISIS brand to oppose Hezbollah in Syria and Lebanon. As a result, most of the Syrian moderates were swept aside or murdered. As more cash has flowed into ISIS pockets during the Syrian Civil War, the group’s influence has grown. In the meantime, Maliki’s government in Iraq has grown closer to Iran, while being propped up by US taxpayers.

Does your head hurt yet? It certainly should.

So why does the West care about one more war in the Land of Infinite Wars?

The collapse of the Iraqi Army is a frustrating embarrassment to the US government. Under the “you break it, you own it” doctrine first stated by US Army General Colin Powell,* both the Obama and Bush administrations have invested heavily in trying to finance and train something that might look vaguely like a functioning government in Iraq. In exchange for our $50,000,000,000 post-war reconstruction extravaganza, which has been managed by a 5,000-strong diplomatic corps, we ended up with something even more chaotic and violent than our worst inner-city ghettos. We ended up with Iraq. So did the poor Iraqis that live there. Americans are a sentimental bunch, and many Americans hate to think that all that reconstruction money we sent to Iraq was a complete waste.

What will the impacts be?

My best guesses are as follows. Neither Iran nor the US will quietly accept a radical Sunni regime in Iraq. If ISIS becomes too powerful, even their Saudi, Kuwaiti, and Qatari backers will grow uncomfortable with their presence and will withhold funding. ISIS will never be able to achieve their dream of consolidating power over all of Iraq, Syria, and Lebanon. They may be able to keep a hold over Sunni dominated areas of Iraq, but they will face a constant struggle to occupy what they have thus far captured.

On the economic front, oil companies will do what they have been doing for a hundred years. They will raise the price of oil beyond any real escalated costs of obtaining crude.

On the political front at home, loyal Republicans will pretend that Iraq was once a great place to live, and they will blame the current disaster on Obama. Loyal Democrats will pretend that Iraq was once a great place to live, and they will blame the current disaster on George Bush. Loyal Americans will likely notice that both administrations demanded far too little of the Iraqi government that we financed and propped up, while thousands of our military members died or suffered serious wounds.

And for the children of Iraq? It’s another sunny day in the Land Between Two Rivers.

Some disinformation is present, notably when talking about Bashar al-Assad and Syria. This video was made in the Western sphere, and as such, there is no surprise about this common disinformation.
What is disinformative in this video is the declaration that Bashar al-Assad started the Syrian civil war. Bashar al-Assad did not start the civil war in Syria. No one person started the Syrian civil war. In 2011, a series of massive protests led to some of the protestors being shot by government forces. This event eventually led to a media announcement by some defectors of the Syrian Army and others to start the 'Free Syrian Army'. In the West, it was portrayed by mainstream media that the 'Free Syrian Army' was heavily organized and moderate, and that the bulk of opposition to Assad was made up of 'moderates. In reality, however, the Free Syrian Army is hardly a unified structure, and the command structure and history of fighting given on Western sources like Wikipedia is very superficial. There are many different groups who claim to be a member of the 'Free Syrian Army,' many of whom are indeed  adherents of some form of radical Islam upset by the secular rule in Syria, lack of Sharia law, and Alawites having a higher social status than others in the country. I've seen many hours of war footage from Syria, and shouting "Allah hu akbar!" 20 times in a row compulsively whilst killing other people and blowing shit up does not indicate to me that a person is a 'moderate'.
Second, there is an ulterior motive for Bashar al-Assad as being portrayed as the root of all evil in the West. Sure, Bashar al-Assad has done many evil things, but there is a specific reason for this portrayal in the West. I think it is logical to analyze the war in Syria as being one part of a neo-Cold War between the United States Military and Vladimir Putin and his gang. I'm going to try to stay on topic here and not talk to much about the neo-Cold War, but just notice that the constant nature of Russia and NATO being at odds everywhere in the world proves this point. With this in mind, it is common knowledge that Bashar al-Assad and Vladimir Putin are allies. Seeking to destroy an alliance between an enemy and their ally is a common strategy to increase a party's global power in the world. As such, this is why the State Department has sought funding for the Syrian rebels fully knowing that most of them are radicals, and why the mainstream media in the United States reports most of them to be 'moderates'. It is also the reason why most people in the United States believe that Bashar al-Assad committed the chemical atrocity in 2013, despite the fact that Bashar al-Assad had everything to lose and nothing to gain from such an atrocity. Because it goes against my common sense that Bashar al-Assad would have ordered such a thing, I believe it to be the rebels who committed the chemical atrocity in order to gain Western support to further destabilize Syria, so that they may have a chance against Bashar al-Assad's army.
Now this double standard has finally blown up in the United States' face. On the one hand, the majority of rebel fighters in Syria are funded by the United States military, and at the same time they are portrayed as 'moderates' and freedom fighters fighting against a discriminatory and evil governance. However, since most of these fighters are Islamic extremists, a small sect of them have trickled into neighboring Iraq, and all of a sudden, this sect is portrayed now more accurately as terrorists, since the United States military wants to keep Iraq stable, and wants to keep Syria unstable and hostile towards Assad at the same time.
